The attack by the Rapid Support Forces took place close to the city of Er Rahad in North Kordofan province, according to the Sudan Doctors Network, which tracks the country‚Äôs war. The vehicle was transporting displaced people who fled fighting in the Dubeiker area, the group said in a statement. Among the dead children were two infants. Continue reading...

In Peru, the gold rush is ravaging the Amazon rainforest. In the department of Madre de Dios, the Guardianes de la Trocha gang has taken over La Pampa, a gold-rich area running alongside the Tambopata National Reserve, one of the most biodiverse regions on the continent. events.title: Weather tracker: Spain and Portugal hit by third deadly storm in two weeks
events.description: Storm Marta sweeps Iberian peninsula just days after Storms Kristin and Leonardo brought deadly flooding and major damage Spain and Portugal have endured another storm over the weekend, just days after the deadly flooding and major damage caused by Storm Kristin and Storm Leonardo last week. Storm Marta passed over the Iberian peninsula on Saturday, bringing fresh torrential rain and killing two people. Storm Kristin killed at least five people after it made landfall on 28 January with Storm Leonardo claiming another victim last Wednesday . The outlook for this week is for more rain across Spain, Portugal and France, especially across north-west Portugal, where more than 100mm is possible during the first half of the week. Some of the heaviest of the rain will transfer to southern Italy and western parts of Greece and Turkey later in the week. Continue reading...

events.title: Police clash with protesters as thousands rally to oppose Israeli president‚Äôs visit ‚Äì as it happened
events.description: This blog is now closed NSW police pepper spray protesters at Sydney rally opposing Isaac Herzog‚Äôs visit Get our breaking news email , free app or daily news podcast Israeli officials outline plan for Isaac Herzog‚Äôs visit Israel‚Äôs government press office has shared a little more public information about Israeli president Isaac Herzog ‚Äôs visit to Australia, as he touched down in Sydney this morning. President Herzog will also attend and address major communal events together with the leaders of the Australian Jewish community. A central part of the visit will be dedicated to official meetings with senior Australian leaders, including the Governor-General and the Prime Minister of Australia, as well as with leaders from across the political spectrum. President Herzog will also conduct interviews with the media during the visit. That‚Äôs a really distorted figure. And why I say that is that figure comes across 150 electorates from around the country. And as Nationals, we only stand in about 20 to 30 seats. So we don‚Äôt run in any city seats. [In] a lot of cities, we wouldn‚Äôt poll at all. We‚Äôd poll zero in Wentworth. We‚Äôd poll zero in Kooyong. We‚Äôd poll zero in Perth because we don‚Äôt stand candidates there. One Nation aren‚Äôt a regional party. I mean, One Nation are running across every seat across the whole country. So I mean it‚Äôs not even comparable in that sense. But you know obviously their figures have gone up very much since post-Bondi, and that has to be noted. Continue reading...

events.title: Christchurch gunman seeks to appeal convictions and withdraw guilty plea
events.description: Australian white supremacist tells NZ court he was suffering from ‚Äònervous exhaustion‚Äô when he entered his guilty plea in March 2020 The Australian white supremacist who murdered 51 Muslim worshippers at two mosques in Christchurch in 2019, in the worst mass shooting in the New Zealand‚Äôs history, has asked a court to discard his guilty pleas, claiming harsh prison conditions had affected his mental health and compelled him to admit to the crimes. Brenton Tarrant pleaded guilty in March 2020 to 51 counts of murder, 40 counts of attempted murder and a terrorism charge, after initially saying he would defend the charges. events.title: Jimmy Lai's evolution from Hong Kong media magnate to activist in photos
events.description: Prominent democracy advocate Jimmy Lai was a child stowaway from mainland China who rose to become Hong Kong‚Äôs onetime media magnate. Unlike other rags-to-riches tycoons who cultivated ties with Beijing, he chose to become its fierce critic. The 78-year-old founder of the now-defunct Apple Daily, a newspaper known for critical reports against both the Hong Kong and Beijing governments, was sentenced to 20 years in prison Monday for his conviction under a China-imposed national security law. Here are 10 key moments in Lai‚Äôs life showing his evolution from a clothing businessman to one of the city‚Äôs best-known pro-democracy activists. 1989: Tiananmen shifts path of clothing chain founder From a child laborer in a glove factory, Lai transformed himself into a clothing entrepreneur, founding the Giordano casual clothing chain in 1981. But the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Beijing changes Lai‚Äôs path. Giordano prints T-shirts in support of the...

Questions over Starmer‚Äôs judgement have intensified, with his chief of staff, Morgan McSweeney, resigning and taking responsibility for the appointment. Thousands of people also protested in Melbourne against Herzog‚Äôs four-day visit, which began on Monday, with some clashing with police. Victoria police appeared to use pepper spray on at least one protester. Continue reading...

events.title: Nikkei index breaks record after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's election victory
events.description: The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo, which tracks the performance of Japan‚Äôs largest companies, hit a new record on Monday after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi‚Äôs ruling Liberal Democratic Party secured a two-thirds majority in the lower house over the weekend. Takaichi ran on an ambitious big-spending agenda, welcomed by investors, although concerns over the country‚Äôs debt load ‚Äìaround 230% of GDP ‚Äì are likely to persist.

events.title: Denis MacShane: Starmer toast? "He's definitely in the toaster"
events.description: British Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer is facing growing scrutiny as tensions rise within his own party. The controversy stems from the Epstein Files, which have put a spotlight on his former US ambassador pick, Peter Mandelson, who resigned last September amid leaked emails linking him to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and now faces a criminal investigation, which he denies. Starmer‚Äôs judgement is under the microscope, and the fallout has claimed his chief of staff, Morgan McSweeney, who resigned, taking responsibility for the appointment. France 24‚Äôs Gavin Lee is joined by Denis MacShane, former Minister of State for Europe under Tony Blair, to discuss the implications for Starmer and the wider political scene.

events.title: Iran sentences Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi to six years in prison
events.description: An Iranian court has sentenced Nobel Peace Prize winner Narges Mohammadi to six years in jail on charges of ‚Äúgathering and collusion to commit crimes‚Äù, her lawyer said Sunday, adding that she was also banned from leaving the country and ordered into internal exile. The verdict, which can be appealed, comes despite serious health concerns for the prominent human rights activist.

events.title: Bermuda snail thought to be extinct now thrives after a decade‚Äôs effort
events.description: Special pods at Chester zoo helped conservationists breed and release more than 100,000 greater Bermuda snails A button-sized snail once feared extinct in its Bermudian home is thriving again after conservationists bred and released more than 100,000 of the molluscs. The greater Bermuda snail ( Poecilozonites bermudensis ) was found in the fossil record but believed to have vanished from the North Atlantic archipelago , until a remnant population was discovered in a damp and overgrown alleyway in Hamilton, the island capital, in 2014 . Continue reading...

events.title: Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong pro-democracy figure, sentenced to 20 years in prison
events.description: Family of media tycoon say he will ‚Äòdie a martyr behind bars‚Äô amid widespread criticism from press freedom groups Jimmy Lai, the media mogul and prominent pro-democracy activist, has been sentenced to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong for national security offences, a punishment his daughter said could mean ‚Äúhe will die a martyr behind bars‚Äù. Claire Lai said the sentence was ‚Äúheartbreakingly cruel‚Äù given her 78-year-old father‚Äôs declining health, while her brother Sebastien Lai called the sentence ‚Äúdraconian‚Äù and ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù.
